verses.text: Hear, O Israel: You are to cross the Jordan today, to go in and dispossess nations greater and mightier than yourself, cities great and fortified up to heaven,
verses.comment: The phrase 'fortified up to heaven' is an idiom meaning high-walled cities.

verses.text: a people great and tall, the sons of the Anakim, whom you know, and of whom you have heard it said: 'Who can stand before the sons of Anak?'
verses.comment: 'Anakim' are a race of giants in the Old Testament.

verses.text: Know therefore today that the LORD your God is he who goes over before you as a consuming fire. He will destroy them and subdue them before you. So you shall drive them out and make them perish quickly, as the LORD has spoken to you.
verses.comment: No significant difference from original meaning.

verses.text: Do not say in your heart, after the LORD your God has driven them out before you, 'It is because of my righteousness that the LORD has brought me in to possess this land,' whereas it is because of the wickedness of these nations that the LORD is driving them out before you.
verses.comment: Translation keeps the Hebraic structure 'do not say in your heart.'

verses.text: It is not for your righteousness or the uprightness of your heart that you are going in to possess their land, but because of the wickedness of these nations the LORD your God is driving them out from before you, and that he may confirm the word that the LORD swore to your fathers, to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.
verses.comment: Reference to the covenant with the patriarchs.

verses.text: Know, therefore, that the LORD your God is not giving you this good land to possess because of your righteousness, for you are a stiff-necked people.
verses.comment: 'Stiff-necked' means stubborn or obstinate.

verses.text: Remember, and do not forget, how you provoked the LORD your God to wrath in the wilderness. From the day you left the land of Egypt until you came to this place, you have been rebellious against the LORD.
verses.comment: Rendered to preserve the original emphasis.

verses.text: Even at Horeb you provoked the LORD to wrath, and the LORD was so angry with you that he was ready to destroy you.
verses.comment: 'Horeb' is an alternative name for Sinai.

verses.text: When I went up the mountain to receive the tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant that the LORD made with you, I remained on the mountain forty days and forty nights. I neither ate bread nor drank water.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'tablets of stone' refers to the Ten Commandments.

verses.text: And the LORD gave me the two tablets of stone written with the finger of God; and on them were all the words that the LORD had spoken with you on the mountain out of the midst of the fire on the day of the assembly.
verses.comment: The 'finger of God' is a figurative expression denoting God's direct action.

verses.text: And at the end of forty days and forty nights the LORD gave me the two tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant.
verses.comment: No significant differences from the original.

verses.text: And the LORD said to me, 'Arise, go down quickly from here, for your people, whom you brought out of Egypt, have acted corruptly. They have quickly turned aside from the way that I commanded them; they have made themselves a molded image.'
verses.comment: 'Molded image' refers to the golden calf.

verses.text: Furthermore the LORD said to me, 'I have seen this people, and behold, it is a stiff-necked people.'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of the phrase 'stiff-necked.'

verses.text: 'Let me alone, that I may destroy them and blot out their name from under heaven; and I will make of you a nation mightier and greater than they.'
verses.comment: 'Blot out their name' is a Hebrew idiom meaning utter destruction.

verses.text: So I turned and came down from the mountain, while the mountain was burning with fire. And the two tablets of the covenant were in my two hands.
verses.comment: Literal and straightforward rendering.

verses.text: And I looked, and behold, you had sinned against the LORD your God. You had made yourselves a molded calf. You had turned aside quickly from the way that the LORD had commanded you.
verses.comment: No significant differences from the original.

verses.text: So I took hold of the two tablets and threw them out of my two hands and broke them before your eyes.
verses.comment: Directly reflects the narrative in Exodus.

verses.text: Then I lay prostrate before the LORD as before, forty days and forty nights. I neither ate bread nor drank water, because of all the sin which you had committed, in doing what was evil in the sight of the LORD to provoke him to anger.
verses.comment: 'Prostrate' means lying face-down in prayer.

verses.text: For I was afraid of the anger and hot displeasure with which the LORD was furious against you, ready to destroy you. But the LORD listened to me that time also.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew parallel structure for emphasis.

verses.text: And the LORD was very angry with Aaron and was ready to destroy him. And I prayed also for Aaron at the same time.
verses.comment: Reflects the strong language of divine anger.

verses.text: Then I took your sin, the calf you had made, and burned it with fire and crushed it, grinding it thoroughly until it was as fine as dust, and I threw its dust into the brook that flowed down from the mountain.
verses.comment: The phrase 'your sin, the calf' is word-for-word from the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: At Taberah also, and at Massah and at Kibroth-hattaavah, you provoked the LORD to wrath.
verses.comment: Transliterates place names for accuracy.

verses.text: And when the LORD sent you from Kadesh-barnea, saying, 'Go up and possess the land that I have given you,' then you rebelled against the command of the LORD your God and did not believe him or obey his voice.
verses.comment: Follows the original text closely.

verses.text: You have been rebellious against the LORD from the day that I knew you.
verses.comment: Word order kept close to Hebrew.

verses.text: So I lay prostrate before the LORD for those forty days and forty nights, because the LORD had said he would destroy you.
verses.comment: Repeats verse 18 for emphasis, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: And I prayed to the LORD and said, 'O Lord GOD, do not destroy your people and your inheritance, whom you redeemed through your greatness, whom you brought out of Egypt with a mighty hand.
verses.comment: 'O Lord GOD'—maintains Hebrew 'Adonai YHWH.'

verses.text: Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Do not look at the stubbornness of this people, or at their wickedness or their sin,
verses.comment: Literal rendering of three faults listed.

verses.text: lest the land you brought us from say, "Because the LORD was not able to bring them into the land that he promised them, and because he hated them, he brought them out to kill them in the wilderness."
verses.comment: Quotation marks indicate direct quote as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Yet they are your people and your inheritance, whom you brought out by your great power and outstretched arm.
verses.comment: 'Outstretched arm' is a Hebrew idiom for God's mighty deeds.
